Job.JobTitle: Mens Assistant Varsity Lacrosse Coach (JV Head Coach) - Lewiston High School
Job.JobDescription:
The Mens Assistant Varsity Lacrosse Coach (JV Head Coach) - Lewiston High School at Lewiston High School is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Mens Assistant Varsity Lacrosse Coach (JV Head Coach) - Lewiston High School manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At Lewiston High School, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Mens Assistant Varsity Lacrosse Coach (JV Head Coach) - Lewiston High School demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Mens Assistant Varsity Lacrosse Coach (JV Head Coach) - Lewiston High School follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Mens Assistant Varsity Lacrosse Coach (JV Head Coach) - Lewiston High School at Lewiston High School allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

SUMMARY: To help each participating student achieve a high level of skill, an appreciation for the values of discipline and sportsmanship, and an increased level of self-esteem.
STIPEND
ESSENTIAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES. Other duties may be assigned.
Coaches individual participants in the skills necessary for excellent achievement in the sport involved. Plans and schedules a regular program of practice in season. Oversees the safety conditions of the facility or area in which assigned sport is conducted at all times that students are present. Maintains accurate statistics, records, and results of the season. Enforces discipline and sportsmanlike behavior at all times, and establishes and oversees penalties for breach of such standards by individual students. Maintains competency in rules, rule interpretations, meet procedures, coaching techniques, and general information about all aspects of the sport. Establishes performance criteria for eligibility in interscholastic competition in this sport. and is consistent in establishing criteria for eligibility in competition. Adheres to a highly efficient and technically sound program of injury prevention and follow up. Works closely with the athletics director in scheduling intramural and interscholastic contests. Recommends purchase of equipment, supplies, and uniforms. Maintains necessary attendance forms, insurance records, and similar paperwork. Accounts for all equipment or delegates the responsibility. Develops a consistent and positive public communications procedure through the school and media to inform the parents and the general public about the athletic program.
SUPERVISORY RESPONSIBILITIES: Supervises students of particular program.
QUALIFICATION REQUIREMENTS: To perform this job successfully, an individual must be able to perform each essential duty satisfactorily. The requirements listed below are representative of the knowledge, skill, and/or ability required. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.
EDUCATION and/or EXPERIENCE: Experience in physical education, coaching, first-aid, CPR, and sports medicine preferred.
LANGUAGE SKILLS: Ability to read and interpret documents such as safety rules, operating and maintenance instructions, and procedure manuals. Ability to write routine reports and correspondence. Ability to speak effectively before groups of students or employees of the district.
MATHEMATICAL SKILLS: Ability to calculate figures and amounts such as discounts, interest, commissions, proportions, percentages, area, circumference, and volume. Ability to apply concepts of basic algebra and geometry.
REASONING ABILITY: Ability to apply common sense understanding to carry out instructions furnished in written, oral, or diagram form. Ability to deal with problems involving several concrete variable standardized situations.
OTHER SKILLS AND ABILITIES:

Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Bonny Eagle Middle School.

The Football Coach, 8th Grade role at Bonny Eagle Middle School is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Football Coach, 8th Grade is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Bonny Eagle Middle School, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Football Coach, 8th Grade sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Bonny Eagle Middle School, the Football Coach, 8th Grade is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Football Coach, 8th Grade at Bonny Eagle Middle School is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

At its core, the Middle School Boys' 7th grade Soccer Head Coach at Kevin Ryan is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Abide by the Scarborough Athletic’s Department Coaches Handbook 2. Abide by all Maine Principals Association rules and regulations 3. Follow and implement all rules and policies within the school & athletic handbooks 4. Equipment inventory & management 5. Ensure athletic participation fee payment by athletes in conjunction with AD’s office 9. Help in the distribution of team rosters, contest schedules and descriptions of contest locations to all players and parents 10. Properly communicate with students and parents as it relates to the SMS communication guide 11. Monitor athlete attendance/behavior/academic status as communicated by the athletic department 12. Communicate all student-athlete injuries to the Athletic Trainer and/or athletic office 13. Attend all school Athletic Department meetings as assigned by the Athletic Director 14. All others as assigned by the Director of Athletics and the Athletic Department Maine State Law requires ALL school employees to be fingerprinted and pass a Criminal History Record Check (CHRC). The Head Football Coach-Lakeland High School at Lakeland High School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Head Football Coach-Lakeland High School is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Lakeland High School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Head Football Coach-Lakeland High School helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Head Football Coach-Lakeland High School works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Lakeland High School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Lakeland High School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Head Football Coach-Lakeland High School reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Head Football Coach-Lakeland High School role at Lakeland High School.

The Girls Swimming and Diving Coach role at Rockford High School is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Girls Swimming and Diving Coach is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Rockford High School, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Girls Swimming and Diving Coach sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Rockford High School, the Girls Swimming and Diving Coach is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Girls Swimming and Diving Coach at Rockford High School is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Girls Varsity Golf Coach manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At Grand Blanc High School, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Girls Varsity Golf Coach demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Girls Varsity Golf Coach follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Girls Varsity Golf Coach at Grand Blanc High School allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

Job.JobDescription:
The 7th Grade Boys Baseball Coach at Deputy Superintendent or Director of Personnel is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the 7th Grade Boys Baseball Coach plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Deputy Superintendent or Director of Personnel reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The 7th Grade Boys Baseball Coach expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the 7th Grade Boys Baseball Coach supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the 7th Grade Boys Baseball Coach may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Deputy Superintendent or Director of Personnel. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Job.JobDescription:
The 8th Grade Football Coach at Grand Blanc East Middle School is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the 8th Grade Football Coach is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Grand Blanc East Middle School, the 8th Grade Football Coach helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The 8th Grade Football Coach may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Grand Blanc East Middle School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The 8th Grade Football Coach follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Job.JobDescription:
The Pom Pon Coach role at Grand Blanc East Middle School is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Pom Pon Coach is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Grand Blanc East Middle School, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Pom Pon Coach sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Grand Blanc East Middle School, the Pom Pon Coach is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Pom Pon Coach at Grand Blanc East Middle School is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Middle School Boys Basketball Coach - Pierce at Pierce Middle School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Assistant Middle School Boys Basketball Coach - Pierce is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Assistant Middle School Boys Basketball Coach - Pierce role at Pierce Middle School.

Job.JobDescription:
The Off-Season Weights/Conditioning Coach position at Raytown South High School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Off-Season Weights/Conditioning Coach prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Raytown South High School, the Off-Season Weights/Conditioning Coach works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Off-Season Weights/Conditioning Coach encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Off-Season Weights/Conditioning Coach at Raytown South High School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job.JobDescription:
Athletic Coach
QUALIFICATIONS: 1. All instructional personnel shall be certified and licensed in accordance with state law and the regulations of the Mississippi Department of Education. Such licensure and transcript of credits shall be on file in the office of the Superintendent of Education. 2. In accordance with Mississippi Code S37-9-17, all personnel employed by the public school system shall be required to pass a criminal background check and a current child abuse registry check. 3. A satisfactory employment record. 4. Can organize and supervise a total sports program. 5. Has previous successful coaching experience in the assigned sport. (Major sports) 6. The head coach must have substantial knowledge of the technical aspects of the sport and, at the same time, must continue to examine new theories and procedures pertinent to the field. 7. The head coach must serve as an appropriate role model for student athletes through his/her instructions and actions. 8. Motor Vehicle Operator's License or ability to provide own transportation.
SUPERVISES: In several instances, the head coach must advise, coordinate, and support a staff of high school assistant coaches and middle school coaches in conjunction with the athletic director and respective principal.
REPORTS TO: Building Principal, Assistant Principal, Sports Coordinator, and or Director
JOB GOAL: To instruct athletes in the fundamental skills, strategy, and physical training necessary for them to realize a degree of individual and team success. At the same time, the coach must instruct and demonstrate behaviors that foster socially acceptable character development, self-discipline, self-confidence, and pride in accomplishment among student athletes. To upgrade his/her knowledge and skills through coaching clinics, observations, consultation, etc.
ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS: Such duties and responsibilities as may be assigned, including but not limited to: 1. Has a thorough knowledge of all the athletic policies approved by the Harrison County School District Board of Education and is responsible for the implementation of the sports program by the entire staff. 2. Knows existing system, state, and league regulations; implements the same consistently and interprets them for staff. 3. Understands the proper administrative line of command and refers all requests or grievances through appropriate channels. Is aware of all public/staff/departmental meetings that require attendance. 4. Established the fundamental philosophy, skills, and techniques to be taught by staff. Designs conferences, clinics, and staff meetings to ensure staff awareness of the overall program. 5. Trains and informs staff and encourages professional growth by encouraging clinic attendance according to local clinic policy. 6. Delegates specific duties, supervises implementation, and, at season's end, analyzes staff effectiveness and evaluates all assistants. 7. Maintains discipline, adjusts grievances, and works to increase morale and cooperation. 8. Performs such other duties as may be assigned by the athletic director/principal.
ADMINISTRATIVE DUTIES: 1. Assists the athletic director in scheduling, providing transportation, and meeting requirements for tournament and special sport events. 2. Assists in the necessary preparation to hold scheduled sports events or practices and adheres to scheduled facility times. Coordinates program with maintenance and school employees. 3. Provides documentation to fulfill state and system requirements concerning physical examinations, parental consent, and eligibility. 4. Provides proper safeguards for maintenance and protection of assigned equipment sites. 5. Advises the athletic director and recommends policy, method, or procedural changes. 6. Serves as a mentor to each athlete to promote the development and demonstration in student athletes the character traits of trustworthiness, respect, responsibility, fairness, caring, and citizenship. 7. Gives constant attention to a student athlete's grades and conduct. 8. By his/her presence at all practices, games, and while traveling, provides assistance, guidance, and safeguards for each participant. 9. Provides training rules and any other unique regulations of the sport to each athlete who is considered a participant. 10. Initiates programs and policies concerning injuries, medical attention, and emergencies. 11. Completes paperwork on all disabling athletic injuries on proper forms and submits to the athletic office within 24 hours. 12. Directs student managers, assistants, and statisticians. 13. Determines discipline, delineates procedures concerning due process when the enforcement of discipline is necessary, and contacts parents when a student is dropped or becomes ineligible. 14. Assists athletes in their college or advanced educational selection. 15. Participates in the budgeting function with the athletic director by establishing requirements for the next season. Recommends equipment guidelines as to type, style, color, or technical specifications. Is responsible for operating within budget appropriations. 16. Is accountable for all equipment and collects the cost of any equipment lost or not returned. Arranges for issuing, storing, and reconditioning of equipment and submits annual inventory and current records concerning same. 17. Properly marks and identifies all equipment before issuing or storing. 18. Monitors equipment rooms and coaches' offices, authorizes who may enter, issue, or requisition equipment. 19. Permits the athletes to only be in authorized areas of the building at the appropriate times. 20. Examines locker rooms before and after practices and games, checking on the general cleanliness of the facility. Responsible for the cleanliness and maintenance of specific sports equipment. 21. Secures all doors, lights, windows, and locks before leaving the building if custodians are not on duty. 22. Instills in each player a respect for equipment and school property, its care, and proper use. 23. Organizes parents, coaches, players, and guests for preseason meetings. 24. Promotes the sport within the school through recruiting athletes who are not in another sports program and promotes the sport outside the school through news media, Little League programs, or in any other feasible manner. 25. Responsible for the quality, effectiveness, and validity of any oral or written release to local media. 26. Responsible for maintaining good public relations with news media, booster club, parents, officials, volunteers, and fans. 27. Presents information to news media concerning schedules, tournaments, and results.
ADDITIONAL DUTIES: Performs other related tasks as assigned by the Principal, Superintendent, and other central office administrators as designated by the Superintendent. Note: The above description is illustrative of tasks and responsibilities. It is not meant to be all-inclusive of every task or responsibility. EQUIPMENT: Standard classroom and athletic materials. TRAVEL REQUIREMENTS: Travel to school district buildings, professional meetings, and athletic events as required. PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS, WORK HAZARDS: Work in standard classroom and school building environments. Note: Also see the Checklist of Duties for the Physical, Sensory, and Environmental Requirements Needed to Perform Essential Functions for this position. TERMS OF EMPLOYMENT: 187-day contract, approximately nine months. The School Board establishes the salary and work year.

TITLE: Non-Faculty Coach QUALIFICATIONS: High School Diploma or GED REPORTS TO: Athletic Director/Principal JOB GOAL: Position is responsible for the specific athletic team/program as assigned. ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS AND RESPONSIBILITIES: 1. Assists the head coach with instructing students in the rules, regulations, equipment, and techniques of the sport. 2. Organizes and directs individual and small group practice activities/exercises as directed by the head coach. 3. Assesses player’s skills, monitors students during competition and practice, and keeps the head coach informed of the athletic performance of students. 4. Assists with determining game strategy. 5. Assists the head coach with supervising athletes during practices and competition. 6. Follows established procedures in the event of an injury. 7. Models sports-like behavior and maintains appropriate conduct towards students, officials, and spectators. 8. Maintains the equipment room in orderly condition and assumes responsibility for its security. 9. Distributes equipment, supplies, and uniforms to students as directed by the head coach. 10. Assists the head coach with submitting a list of award winners at the end of the season. 11. Participates in special activities to include parent’s night, banquets, award nights, and pep assemblies. 12. Performs support tasks such as distributing and maintaining eligibility forms, emergency data cards, and other related records. 13. Models nondiscriminatory practices in all activities. Terms of Employment: Duration of Coaching Season Starting Salary and/or Grade: Non-Faculty Coach Stipend Knowledge, Skills and Abilities: Must have the ability to sit and stand for extended periods of time; exhibit manual dexterity to dial a telephone, see and read a computer screen and printed material with or without vision aids; hear and understand speech at normal levels, outdoors and on the telephone; speak in audible tones so that others may understand clearly; physical agility to lift up to 25 pounds to shoulder height and 50 pounds to waist height; and to bend, to stoop, to sit on the floor, to climb stairs, to walk and to reach overhead. Some experience as a Wrestling coach at the high school or college level preferred. Must possess effective coaching techniques and skills. Must possess some knowledge of the rules, regulations, strategies, and techniques of the sport. Must possess the ability to establish and maintain effective working relationships with school administrators, parents, and students.

The Head Coach - Volleyball (Women) role at Carrboro High School is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Head Coach - Volleyball (Women) is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Carrboro High School, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Head Coach - Volleyball (Women) sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Carrboro High School, the Head Coach - Volleyball (Women) is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Head Coach - Volleyball (Women) at Carrboro High School is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Job.JobDescription:
The JV Cheerleading Coach at Chapel Hill High School is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the JV Cheerleading Coach is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Chapel Hill High School, the JV Cheerleading Coach helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The JV Cheerleading Coach may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Chapel Hill High School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The JV Cheerleading Coach follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Soccer Coach (Women) Spring 2026 position at East Chapel Hill High School is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Assistant Soccer Coach (Women) Spring 2026 is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At East Chapel Hill High School, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Assistant Soccer Coach (Women) Spring 2026 encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Assistant Soccer Coach (Women) Spring 2026 also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Assistant Soccer Coach (Women) Spring 2026 role at East Chapel Hill High School is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Lacrosse Coach (Men) Spring 2026 at East Chapel Hill High School is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Assistant Lacrosse Coach (Men) Spring 2026 plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at East Chapel Hill High School reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Assistant Lacrosse Coach (Men) Spring 2026 expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Assistant Lacrosse Coach (Men) Spring 2026 supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Assistant Lacrosse Coach (Men) Spring 2026 may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at East Chapel Hill High School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

POSITION PURPOSE To instruct student athletes in the fundamental skills, strategy, and physical training necessary for them to realize a degree of individual and team success. At the same time, the student shall receive instruction that will lead to the formulation of moral values, pride of accomplishment, acceptable social behavior, self-discipline and self-confidence.
MINIMUM QUALIFICATION STANDARDS KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES Ability to organize and supervise a total sports program Previous successful coaching experience Substantial knowledge of the technical aspects of the sport and at the same time must continue to examine new theories and procedures pertinent to the sport Must know and follow the rules of the North Carolina High School Athletic Association, the North Carolina Department of Public Instruction, and the Pender County Board of Education
EDUCATION, TRAINING, AND EXPERIENCE Successful completion of the NFHS “Fundamentals of Coaching” certification course Annual completion of the NFHS “Concussions in Sports” course or an equivalent concussion curriculum prior to the first date of practice in their sport If coaching cheerleading, must complete the NFHS “American Association of Cheerleading Coaches Spirit Safety Certification” course prior to the first date of practice Current CPR/AED certification; recommended to successfully complete the NFHS “First Aid for Coaches” course Must complete the NFHS “Sudden Cardiac Arrest” Course after June 1 and prior to the first practice All high school head coaches must attend one of the NCHSAA state rules clinics in their assigned sport.
CERTIFICATION AND LICENSE REQUIREMENTS Must hold and maintain a valid motor vehicle operator’s license according to the State of NC requirements
SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS Ability to work flexible hours (evenings, weekends)
PREFERRED QUALIFICATIONS Hold valid driver license for driving an activity bus in Pender County Schools Be a bona fide member of the school faculty Be an Accredited Interscholastic Coach or Certified Interscholastic Coach by the NFHS Playing experience at the high school and college level
ESSENTIAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES Holds organizational meetings for team prospects and encourages potential athletes to participate in the sport Assesses a player’s skill and assigns team positions Develops a regular practice schedule and organizes practice time to provide both team and individual development Works with the athletic director to schedule facilities for practices and competitions Assigns duties to an assistant coach as necessary Coaches and instructs players, individually or in groups, regarding the rules, regulations, equipment, and techniques of the sport Observes players, during competition and practice to determine the needs for individual or team improvement Determines game strategy based on the team’s capabilities Establishes and maintains standards of student behavior and provides proper supervision of athletes at all times Monitors the academic performance of team members to ensure that eligibility standards are met; and encourages student athletes to maintain high academic standards Follows established procedures in the event of an athlete’s injury Conferences with parents/guardians, as necessary, regarding the athletic performance of their student Follows state, conference, and district regulations governing the athletic program Models and maintains appropriate conduct and behavior towards players, officials, and spectators Acts a team representative and promotes the sport by communicating with booster clubs, service organizations, and the school community Maintains and cares for equipment, supplies, and uniforms, including correct inventory of same Assist with the maintenance of athletic playing areas (i.e. mowing grass, picking up debris, operating a weed eater) Attends staff development, clinics, and other professional activities to improve performance Performs other duties as assigned by the Principal and Athletic Director
WORKING CONDITIONS PHYSICAL DEMANDS Must be able to use a variety of office equipment such as computers and copiers Must be able to frequently sit, carry, push, pull or otherwise move objects up to 20 pounds Due to the amount of time spent working on the computer, standing and walking, physical requirements are consistent with those for light work
WORK ENVIRONMENT Must be able to work in office and public school environments, and come into direct contact with staff and students Travel is required to schools and Central Services offices

The Head Athletic Coach - JV Lacrosse monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Head Athletic Coach - JV Lacrosse must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Topsail High School.

Position Title: Varsity Assistant Coach – Girls Basketball Location: Sheyenne High School Department: Athletics/Activities Reports To: Athletic Director Term: 2025-26 Season Schedule: See Summary for more information. Salary: Position follows the Activities Pay Schedule 2025-2027 Date of last review: August 2025
SUMMARY: The Varsity Assistant – Girls Basketball position is responsible for leading the team in training, instruction, conditioning, and performance. The position provides support and education to athletes in an effort to excel in their given sport in a healthy and safe environment. The position views winning not only as success, but as helping team members reach goals.
Schedule: The schedule and hours for this position vary and aligns to the NDHSAA schedule. For questions regarding the schedule, please contact the building-level athletic director.
To Apply: Please complete the application and include three references.
QUALIFICATION REQUIREMENTS: To perform this job successfully, an individual must be able to perform each essential duty and requirement satisfactorily. The requirements listed below are representative of the knowledge, skills, and/or abilities required for the role. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.
ESSENTIAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES: (Other duties may be assigned) Collaboration: • Leads training, instruction, conditioning, performance, and selection of athletes. Communication: • Communicates with other coaches, assistant coaches, and athletes in a professional and respectful manner. • Communicates with athletes to provide helpful, positive guidance to ensure athlete growth and safety. • Communicates with officials, opposing coaches, parents, and others in a positive, respectful manner. Providing exemplary behavior for athletes and other learners. Compassion: • Demonstrates and generates, among staff and athletes, an attitude of good sportsmanship and fair play by adhering to the “Coach’s Code of Ethics” and our conference “Sportsmanship Guidelines.” • Understands the complexities of cultural and global issues and how they relate to employee and learners' experiences. • Approaches coaching with a positive, committed mindset. Focusing on athlete well-being. • Develops positive working relationships with school administration, learners, educators, and the wider district community. Creativity: • Connects with team members and shares ideas in an effort to improve the overall learner and employee experience. Critical Thinking: • Develops, organizes, and implements effective practices for athletes to teach proper skills and strategies to compete at an elevated level. Reflection: • Maintains communication with supervisor and director regarding general feedback, career advancement opportunities, and areas of growth opportunities. Resilience: • Maintains composure while dealing with stressful situations. • Proactively seeks out resolutions and takes initiative to resolve knowledge gaps. Responsibility: • Adheres to all West Fargo Public Schools and NDHSAA guidelines and policies. • Provides for the health, safety, and well-being of team members at practices, games, and transportation to and from activities.
PHYSICAL DEMANDS AND WORK ENVIRONMENT: The physical demands and work environment described here are representative of those that must be met by an employee to successfully perform the essential functions of this job. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions. • While performing the essential duties and responsibilities of this role, the employee is regularly required to reach with hands and arms. • While performing the essential duties and responsibilities of this role, the employee is regularly required to stand, walk, bend, talk, and hear. • The specific vision abilities required for this role include close and peripheral vision. • The employee may frequently lift up to ~25 pounds without assistance. • The employee may occasionally lift up to ~50 pounds without assistance. • The employee may have to push/pull up to ~120 pounds while performing the duties of the role. • The employee must work with the public and various WFPS staff while simultaneously managing several competing demands. • The employee may work outdoors and, if so, will be exposed to the applicable weather elements. • The employee may come in contact with bloodborne pathogens or other bodily fluids on rare occasions. • The employee will work in an environment that has a quiet to loud noise level.
Education and/or Experience: • Currently possesses, or has the ability to obtain, an NDHSAA coaching certification. • Experience in the discipline is preferred.

Job.JobTitle: Assistant Coach - Boys Swim and Dive
Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Coach - Boys Swim and Dive at Sheyenne High School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Assistant Coach - Boys Swim and Dive is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Sheyenne High School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Assistant Coach - Boys Swim and Dive helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Assistant Coach - Boys Swim and Dive works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Sheyenne High School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Sheyenne High School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Assistant Coach - Boys Swim and Dive reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Assistant Coach - Boys Swim and Dive role at Sheyenne High School.

A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Alvirne High School reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Spring 2026 Girls Varsity Tennis Coach expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Spring 2026 Girls Varsity Tennis Coach supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Spring 2026 Girls Varsity Tennis Coach may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Alvirne High School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Job.JobTitle: Swim Head Coach - Massabesic Middle School
Job.JobDescription: Regional School Unit 57 Position: Massabesic Middle School Swim Head Coach Qualifications 1. Ability to organize and supervise a comprehensive athletic program. 2. Previous successful coaching experience in the assigned sport. 3. Substantial knowledge of the technical aspects of swimming, with a commitment to ongoing professional learning and the application of new theories and best practices. 4. Ability to serve as a positive role model for student-athletes through professional conduct, instruction, and leadership. Reports To The Athletic Director, who provides overall objectives and conducts the final evaluation in conjunction with the appropriate school principal(s). Supervises When applicable, advises, coordinates, and supports assistant and middle school coaching staff in collaboration with the Athletic Director and respective principal. Job Goal To instruct student-athletes in fundamental skills, strategy, and physical training necessary for individual and team success. The coach will also promote character development, self-discipline, self-confidence, and pride of accomplishment, while continuously upgrading professional knowledge through clinics, observations, and consultation. General Expectations 1. Recognizes that the success of athletic programs strongly influences the community's perception of the school system. Community and parent pressure to win must never override the values of sportsmanship, student well-being, and mental health. 2. Acknowledges that the position may require extended time commitments and involves inherent risks and due process considerations. 3. Exercises sound judgment and common sense in situations not explicitly addressed in this job description. Duties and Responsibilities Program Oversight 1. Demonstrates thorough knowledge of all athletic policies approved by RSU 57 and ensures their consistent implementation. 2. Understands and enforces system, state, and league regulations, interpreting them clearly for staff and athletes. 3. Follows the proper administrative chain of command and attends required meetings. Staff Responsibilities 1. Establishes and communicates the fundamental philosophy, skills, and techniques to be taught within the program. 2. Trains and supports coaching staff and encourages professional growth through approved clinics and development opportunities. 3. Delegates duties, supervises implementation, and evaluates staff effectiveness at the conclusion of the season. 4. Maintains discipline, addresses grievances, and promotes morale and cooperation. 5. Performs other duties as assigned by the Athletic Director or principal. Administrative Duties 1. Assists the Athletic Director with scheduling, transportation, and preparation for meets and special events. 2. Coordinates facility use and works with maintenance and school staff to ensure readiness for practices and events. 3. Maintains required documentation for physical examinations, parental consent, and eligibility. 4. Ensures proper care, maintenance, and security of assigned equipment and facilities. 5. Recommends policy, procedural, or program improvements to the Athletic Director. Student Responsibilities 1. Serves as a mentor, promoting character traits such as trustworthiness, respect, responsibility, fairness, caring, and citizenship. 2. Monitors and supports student-athletes' academic performance and conduct. 3. Provides supervision and safeguards for student-athletes during practices, competitions, and travel. 4. Communicates training rules and sport-specific expectations to all participants. 5. Implements procedures for injury prevention, medical care, and emergency response. 6. Completes and submits injury reports within 24 hours when required. 7. Directs and supervises student managers and assistants. 8. Enforces discipline in accordance with due process and communicates with parents as necessary. 9. Supports student-athletes with future educational or athletic planning when appropriate. Finance and Equipment 1. Participates in budgeting by identifying program needs and operating within approved allocations. 2. Maintains accountability for all equipment, including inventory, storage, issuance, and reconditioning. 3. Ensures proper identification, security, and authorized access to equipment and facilities. 4. Oversees locker room and facility cleanliness and ensures equipment is properly maintained. 5. Secures facilities upon departure and promotes respect for school property among student-athletes. Public Relations 1. Organizes and leads preseason meetings for parents and student-athletes. 2. Promotes the swim program within the school and community to encourage participation. 3. Ensures accuracy and professionalism in communications with local media. 4. Maintains positive relationships with parents, officials, volunteers, booster organizations, and the community. 5. Shares schedules, results, and program highlights with appropriate audiences. This job description is intended to provide general guidance and does not limit the assignment of additional responsibilities as needed.

Job.JobTitle: Head Wrestling Coach - Massabesic Middle School
Job.JobDescription: Regional School Unit 57 Position Title: Head Wrestling Coach Reports To: High School Athletic Director, in conjunction with the Principal Qualifications Knowledge and background in the sport of wrestling. Meets RSU 57 eligibility requirements, including: First Aid Certification CPR Certification Concussion Management Course Heat Acclimatization Course RSU 57 Background Check Maine Department of Education Criminal History Record Check All requirements must be met within timelines specified by RSU 57. * Position Summary The Head Wrestling Coach is responsible for the planning, organization, supervision, and evaluation of the high school wrestling program. The Head Coach instructs student-athletes in fundamental skills, strategy, and physical conditioning necessary to achieve individual and team success while supporting the mission and athletic philosophy of RSU 57. Essential Duties and Responsibilities Organize and supervise all aspects of the high school wrestling program. Demonstrate thorough knowledge of local, state, and school athletic policies and procedures. Implement and enforce athletic department policies and team rules. Attend all required meetings as scheduled by the school, Athletic Director, and Maine Principals' Association (MPA). Emphasize the importance of academics, sportsmanship, citizenship, and character development as part of the athletic philosophy. Maintain high standards for athlete performance and conduct. Model appropriate behavior, professionalism, and sportsmanship at all times. Dress appropriately for practices, competitions, and meetings. Apply sound knowledge of the sport, including training and conditioning techniques. Seek opportunities for professional growth and incorporate new techniques and ideas when appropriate. Teach skills that are developmentally appropriate and safe for individual student-athletes. Supervise student-athletes at all times to ensure safety and accountability. Maintain, inventory, store, and care for athletic equipment and uniforms. Inspect equipment and facilities regularly to ensure safe conditions. Prepare for and supervise all scheduled practices, competitions, and events. Establish, communicate, and enforce appropriate team rules and expectations. Utilize appropriate emergency procedures and injury response protocols. Encourage leadership and positive behavior among student-athletes on and off the mat. Communicate promptly, professionally, and appropriately with parents and guardians. Participate in preseason informational meetings with parents/guardians and athletes. Interact effectively and appropriately with officials, opponents, and event personnel. Meet all deadlines for paperwork and related duties. Maintain required records and documentation for student-athletes. Perform other duties as assigned by the Athletic Director or Principal. Language and Communication Skills Ability to read and interpret documents relevant to the position, including athletic policies, handbooks, and state guidelines. Ability to communicate clearly, concisely, and correctly in both oral and written form with parents, athletes, coaches, administrators, and officials. Ability to establish and maintain effective working relationships with administrators, coaching staff, athletes, parents, and the community. Mathematical Skills Basic understanding of budgeting, inventory management, and record-keeping practices. Physical Demands While performing the essential duties of this position, the employee is regularly required to stand, walk, talk, and hear. The position frequently requires physical demonstration of skills, including running, jumping, throwing, grappling techniques, and general body movement. The employee may be required to lift and carry items weighing more than 20 pounds. Occasional prolonged sitting and frequent travel by bus are required. Extended hours may be necessary to meet the demands of the position.
